COMMODITIES

EIA stated that US crude oil production rose by 260k BPD in February to 10.264mln BPD (Prev. 10.004mln BPD in January), while US total oil demand (Feb) rose 2.4% Y/Y or 460,00 BPD to 19.619mln BPD, (January saw a 6.3% rise). (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

Israel PM Netanyahu said Iran has been hiding nuclear weapons activity and that Israel can provide "new and conclusive proof" of this. Israeli PM Netanyahu was said to seek a vote to enable the Defence Minister to decide on war in extreme circumstances, while there were also reports Israel said to have closed airspace near the Golan Heights (East of the Jordan River and Israel/Syria border). (Newswires/Ynet)

Iran Foreign Minister tweeted that Iran allegations are old allegations that have already been dealt with by the IAEA. (Twitter)

US

US Core PCE Price Index YY (Mar) 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 1.6%). (Newswires)
US Personal Income MM (Mar) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%, Rev. 0.3%)
US Personal Consumption Real MM (Mar) 0.40% vs. Exp. 0.50% (Prev. 0.00%, Rev. -0.20%)
US Consumption, Adjusted MM (Mar) 0.40% vs. Exp. 0.40% (Prev. 0.20%)


MARKET RECAP

Ahead of the cash open, US equity futures were firmer, rising back into the black for the year, after consolidating under the neutral line for most of Friday trade. However, as the cash day got underway, traders were reported to have become concerned about the USD strength (DXY is up over 2.5% from April lows, leading many analysts to change their tune on the buck) though yields on 10yr Treasuries didn’t threaten the dreaded 3% level, which has been a trigger for equity weakness in recent sessions. Additionally, traders were said to be concerned on the geopolitical front, after Israel closed airspace in the Golan Heights ahead of an announcement on Iran (see Geopolitics section) which began to see a classic risk-off move (equities down, Treasuries up, oil up, gold up). SPX -0.82% at 2648, NDX -0.76% at 6606, DJI -0.61% at 24163.

The yield curve flattened on Monday on a combination of month-end and softish data, causing the 10yr yield to retreat from last week’s best levels, falling to sub-2.94%. While most of the action was concentrated in the long-end of the curve (30s yields down c.2bps at settlement), all the major yield spreads were narrowing; 5s30s flattened by c.1bps the lowest spread in more than six years. Ahead of Wednesday’s Quarterly Refunding Announcement, the US Treasury borrowed USD 488bln in Q1, expectations are to issue USD 75bln in net marketable debt in Q2, down USD 101bln previous estimate, and USD 273bln in net marketable debt in Q3. Elsewhere, BTPs underperformed their peers on Monday after Italy’s 5SM leader Di Maio called for a fresh elections in June. Following the election in March, talks between parties have largely failed and no successful attempts were made to form a government. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 4 ticks higher at 119-20.

US MARKET WRAP 30 April 2018: Oil jumps on geopolitics; heavy M&A activity
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, DXY up, Crude up.
* REAR-VIEW: Israel says Iran lied about nuke activity; core PCE jumps; heavy M&A activity.
* AHEAD: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin to speak 17.30EST/22.30BST, RBA overnight, Labour Day in Europe; Apple, BP, Pfizer and Merck among the big names reporting on Tues; API inventories, GDT auction.

 

* GEOPOLITICS: Attention was on Iran again today, ahead of the 12 May decision that the US must make on whether to pull-out of the nuclear deal. Traders were on alert after Israel closed airspace over Golan Heights and announced PM Netanyahu would be making a key announcement later in the day, which lent strength to the crude complex. At the press conference, the Israeli PM accused Iran of lying over its nuclear intentions, and claimed that it had proof that Iran continued its nuclear programme after the nuclear deal was signed. Israel also told the US that it would be prepared to target Iran if it is attacked from Syria by Iranian proxies. Iran denied the allegations.

* TRADE WARS: There are two key US trade policy decisions due this week: 1) Whether to roll steel and aluminium tariff exemptions (1/May), and 2) NAFTA decision (possibly by 4/May). US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin will visit Beijing for showdown trade talks on Thursday and Friday, and ahead of this week’s deadlines, he said that Trump would not be commenting on EU tariff exemptions; on that subject, FT sources reported that the mood is said to be darkening on EU/US trade dispute following latest contacts with US administration. Talking NAFTA, Mexico's automakers association AMIA, commented on the new US auto proposal saying it is not a viable one given the situation of the industry the US. It included a 75% in regional autos content to be implemented in 4 years for light vehicles and 2 years for trucks.

* DATA: Small misses on the headline for Personal Income and Spending, but analysts have been encouraged by the general trend in consumption growth. Capital Economics said the rise in real consumption in March confirms that all of the first-quarter weakness in household spending came at the very beginning of the year, and that consumption growth is already rebounding. The core PCE will have been of interest to the Fed, with the YY headline rising to 1.9%, which analysts believe will keep the FOMC on track to lift rates at least two more times in 2018. Pending home sales missed expectations, and are running below the pace implied by mortgage applications data, Pantheon Macroeconomics notes. It was a disappointing report, Pantheon said, consistent with a clear drop in April existing home sales. “Relative cold and snowy weather in March might have depressed activity; we look for better numbers in April.” Meanwhile, in Europe, German flash HICP in April was a touch weaker than expected with core components contributing to the downside, which analysts say supports the ECB’s cautious policy approach.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.82% at 2648, NDX -0.76% at 6606, DJI -0.61% at 24163 SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.40%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.75%, Energy: +0.31%, Financials: -0.56%, Health Care: -1.18%, Industrials: -1.09%, Materials: -1.67%, Technology: -0.45%, Telecoms: -2.36%, Utilities: -0.34%. Ahead of the cash open, US equity futures were firmer, rising back into the black for the year, after consolidating under the neutral line for most of Friday trade. However, as the cash day got underway, traders were reported to have become concerned about the USD strength (DXY is up over 2.5% from April lows, leading many analysts to change their tune on the buck) though yields on 10yr Treasuries didn’t threaten the dreaded 3% level, which has been a trigger for equity weakness in recent sessions. Additionally, traders were said to be concerned on the geopolitical front, after Israel closed airspace in the Golan Heights ahead of an announcement on Iran (see Geopolitics section) which began to see a classic risk-off move (equities down, Treasuries up, oil up, gold up).

* M&A news dominated over earnings on Monday; Walmart (WMT) announced over the weekend it is to sell its UK ASDA unit to Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) for $10bln (£7.3bln) which will make the merged entity, if approved, larger than the UK’s current market leader, Tesco (TSCO LN). Also, T-Mobile (TMUS) & Sprint (S) confirmed they are to merge in a $26bln deal, however analysts are noting it is likely to face challenges from the US DoJ. However, Fox’s Gasparino tweeted source reports that DoJ officials told Fox that the antitrust division found the deal less problematic than AT&T’s (T) and Time Warner’s (TWX) deal. Elsewhere, Prologis (PLD) announced it is to acquire DCT Industrial Trust (DCT) for $8.4bln deal and finally, Marriot Vacations (VAC) announced it would purchase ILG (ILG) in a deal worth $4.7bln.

* The largest earnings report today came from McDonald’s (MCD) who beat on both the top and bottom lines, while its global same store sales rose 5.5%, above analyst expectations of 3.7%, and US same store sales were in line at 2.9%. Tomorrow’s highly anticipated earnings slate includes Apple (AAPL), Pfizer (PFE) and Merck (MRK). Over the weekend, press reports suggested that Apple (AAPL) is looking to increase shareholder wealth by roughly $100bln as it prepare to redistribute its repatriated overseas profits, with some expecting apple to announce a record breaking expansion to its capital return scheme alongside its earnings report (currently the tech behemoth is on track to total buybacks and dividends around $300bln by March in 2019, but the likes of  Morgan Stanley believes that Apple could announce a further $150bln to that sum tomorrow, while Citi expects another $100bln increase, RBC sees $80bln-$90bln over four-five years); expectations: EPS $2.69, revenues $61.2bln, iPhones sales 53mln, iPads 9mln and Macs 4mln.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 4 ticks higher at 119-20. The yield curve flattened on Monday on a combination of month-end and softish data, causing the 10yr yield to retreat from last week’s best levels, falling to sub-2.94%. While most of the action was concentrated in the long-end of the curve (30s yields down c.2bps at settlement), all the major yield spreads were narrowing; 5s30s flattened by c.1bps the lowest spread in more than six years. Ahead of Wednesday’s Quarterly Refunding Announcement, the US Treasury borrowed USD 488bln in Q1, expectations are to issue USD 75bln in net marketable debt in Q2, down USD 101bln previous estimate, and USD 273bln in net marketable debt in Q3. Elsewhere, BTPs underperformed their peers on Monday after Italy’s 5SM leader Di Maio called for a fresh elections in June. Following the election in March, talks between parties have largely failed and no successful attempts were made to form a government.

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle 47 cents higher at $68.57/bbl; Brent settles 53 cents higher at $75.17. Oil traded near fresh YTD highs after Israeli PM Netanyahu presented evidence that purportedly shows Iran has been lying about its nuclear intentions, and has been hiding nuclear weapons activity. President Trump continued to be coy, and said ‘we will see what happens’ when asked about pulling out of the Iran deal, adding that pulling out of the Iran deal would provide a positive message to North Korea.

* Ahead of tomorrow’s API energy report, analysts forecast crude stocks will build by 1.3mln, Cushing (via Genscape)is forecast to build by 1mln, distillates are seen drawing 1.3mln, and gasoline is seen drawing by 0.4mln. A Reuters poll sees analysts raising their crude oil forecasts, and now see crude averaging $63.23/bbl in 2018, and $62.16 in 2019 (vs $59.85 and $58.65 in last month’s poll). Finally, Reuters latest OPEC survey expects OPEC April oil output seen declining 70k BPD to 32.12mln BPD, lowest since April 2017 led by Venezuela, Nigeria and Angola; Compliance with output cut deal expected to rise to 162% (from 161%).

* Es Sider port loadings are reported to be 310k in May, highest since the 2016 restart of the Es Sider pipeline; Libya on Sunday also said that the El Sharara field is pumping more than 300k BPD; UAE’s ADNOC has informed clients that the June allocations will be cut by 5% for all crude grades.

* FOREX: DXY The USD and index are heading into the final few hours of April on a firmer footing and could conceivably retest recent peaks just under 92.000 with more in line or above forecast data. In truth, the Greenback has gleaned a lot of upward momentum from the demise of its currency rivals, but rising US Treasury yields have been a related factor alongside solid economic indicators. Technically, the DXY really needs to clear 91.900 and out of a rising channel to take on any psychological resistance around the next big figure and advance further towards the nearest bullish chart target beyond that circa 92.329.

* AUD and NZD Both edging ominously close to round number supports that could easily trigger more heavy losses if breached at 0.7500 and 0.7000 respectively as the aforementioned climb in US cash rates eats into any residual yield advantage the antipodeans have. The AUD has just been outperforming or rather holding up better than the Kiwi during the latter part of the month on cross flows as 1.0700 is reclaimed vs a few pips below 1.0500 in mid-April. Looking ahead, the RBA meeting looms overnight, but is not expected to provide the AUD with much support, while NZ jobs data is due on Tuesday.

* EUR/CHF/JPY Still broadly keeping pace with each other and between 0.25-0.35% adrift the Dollar, but with the single currency back below 1.2100 after a soft German HICP print (y/y) and eyeing key Fib support around 1.2055 again, ahead of early 2018 lows at 1.2030. USDCHF has now climbed above 0.9900, while USDJPY remains contained within a 109.00-50 range amidst rising mid-East jitters ahead of a speech by Israeli PM Netanyahu on Iran (18.00BST/20.00PM local), but not threatening decent option expiry interest at the low end (1.4 bn) at the NY cut.

* GBP Cable has bounced off major technical support near early March lows (circa 1.3712-15) to 1.3750 or thereabouts, while EURGBP is back below 0.8800 vs peaks earlier around 0.8825, but Sterling is still at risk of ending April with net losses having rallied vs the USD for 13 consecutive years during this month. A drastic reduction in May BoE tightening expectations on sub forecast and/or downright weak data has done the damage, along with more political fall-out and doubts about a Brexit transition deal.

* USDCAD steadier around 1.2850 with the Loonie gleaning support from a sharp rebound in crude prices on the aforementioned geopolitical/mid-east uncertainty, and hopes of an early May NAFTA deal. On the domestic front, GDP data and BoC’s Poloz due tomorrow, and after firm PPI/raw material prices

* COMING-UP: RBA MEETING: Expectations are one-sided for the central bank to keep the Cash Rate Target unchanged at the record low 1.50% for a 19th consecutive month. Recent commentary from the central bank have all been reiterations as RBA Governor Lowe repeated that it is more likely the next move in the cash rate will be up rather than down. Data suggests that the RBA is unlikely to begin rate normalization soon as latest inflation figures showed softer than expected headline CPI for Q1. Click here to read full report.

subject: Summary of US NAFTA auto proposals
content:
• proposal would live regional value content to 75% from 62.5%
  • proposal calls for 4 year phase-in for passenger vehicles, two-year phase-in for pickup trucks with possibility of two-year extensions
  • allows up to 15 percentage points of labor value content to come from research, product development sales, software activities
  • requires 70% regional value content for steel aluminum purchased by original equipment manufacturers
  • proposal would require a $16 wage on work comprising 40% of the value of light-duty passenger vehicles and 45% for pickup trucks. 
  • The wage demand are aimed at preserving US and Canadian auto production and putting upward pressure on Mexico's low auto wages
  • It is estimated that Mexican auto assembly workers average under $6 an hour, with workers in parts plants averaging less than $3 an hour

Via ForexLive

UBS Weekly FX Flows Report: USD bid; EUR sold for 4th week
content:
• EURUSD: EURUSD saw largest outflows since Nov. 2016, as asset managers and hedge funds were heavy sellers while corporates and private clients were marginal buyers.
  • USDJPY, EURJPY: USDJPY was bought for the 4th consecutive week, as buying interest from hedge funds and corporate clients exceeded selling from asset managers and private clients. JPY saw inflows versus EUR, led primarily by hedge fund buying, as all other clients showed limited directionality.
  • GBPUSD, EURGBP: GBPUSD was net sold, as private clients and corporates led outflows while asset managers and hedge funds showed limited directionality. GBP saw inflows vs EUR, as selling from private clients and corporates was more than offset by buying from asset managers and hedge funds.
  • EURCHF, USDCHF: CHF saw marginal inflows versus EUR, as buying from asset managers and private clients slightly exceeded selling from corporates and hedge funds. USDCHF registered strong inflows, as buying from hedge funds and asset managers dominated selling from corporates and private clients.
  • AUDUSD, NZDUSD, and USDCAD: AUD saw outflows versus USD, as private clients were the only client group not to register selling interest. NZDUSD was also sold, led predominately by hedge fund selling as other client groups showed limited directionality. CAD saw marginal outflows vs USD as selling from hedge funds and corporates slightly exceeded buying from asset managers and private clients.
  • EURSEK, EURNOK, USDSEK, and USDNOK: EURSEK saw inflows, led almost exclusively by asset managers, as all other clients showed limited directionality. NOK saw outflows versus EUR, as all client groups registered outflows except for private clients. USDSEK was bought for a 5th straight week, led by asset managers and hedge funds. USDNOK saw outflows, as hedge funds led all client groups in selling interest.

Cable has bounced off major technical support near early March lows (circa 1.3712-15) to 1.3750 or thereabouts, while Eur/Gbp is back below 0.8800 vs peaks earlier around 0.8825, but Sterling is still at risk of ending April with net losses having rallied vs the Usd for 13 consecutive years during this month. A drastic reduction in May BoE tightening expectations on sub forecast and/or downright weak data has done the damage, along with more political fall-out and doubts about a Brexit transition deal.

CAD         

Usd/Cad steadier around 1.2850 with the Loonie gleaning support from a sharp rebound in cride prices on the aforementioned geopolitical/mid-east uncertainty, and hopes of an early May NAFTA deal. On the domestic front, GDP data and BoC’s Poloz due tomorrow, and after firm PPI/raw material prices today.

subject: BofAML remains an 'unabashed dollar bull', offers more reasons to sell EURUSD now
content:
• BofAML says even more significant than the recent USD rally is the return of the USD-interest rate differential correlation, which it sees as a sign that interest rate insensitive FX flows are slowing or even ending.
  • "Two such flows – rebalancing/diversification of reserves and investor clear preference for Eurozone over US equities – have been weighing heavily on the USD over the past year. If we are right," BofAML says, "the USD rally in the past week is just the beginning. We remain unabashed USD bulls."

BofAML's reasons to sell EURUSD:

  • Continued soft Eurozone data in April discredits the “bad weather" theory but lends support to the “euro is too strong” theory.
  • In the US, the recent upturn in business investment is paving the way for higher productivity and wage growth.
  • A NAFTA deal over the next few weeks should increase US leverage in trade negotiations with China
  • Corporate America may use the Q1 earning season to repatriate their offshore cash
  • Continued Chinese deleveraging will limit the ability of the PBOC to match further Fed hikes
  • The flatness (steepness) of the US (Eurozone) yield curve means foreign investors will only consider currency unhedged (hedged) investment in US (Eurozone) bonds
  • The fiscal risk premium in the USD is already very high
  • Divergence between momentum and positioning are turning the tables on over-extended EUR longs

subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds edge up, Dollar dips post-US data
content: Mixed US data on balance, but core PCE staying below the Fed’s 2% target seems to have resonated with markets on the basis that the more hawkish FOMC members cannot declare victory on inflation this week. Hence, a grinding bid in core bonds and marginal new session peaks in the process, with Bunds up to 158.75 (+9 ticks vs -28 ticks at worst) and also supported by weaker than forecast German HICP in y/y terms. Gilts have now edged to 122.32 (+39 ticks) and the US Treasury curve is flattening further as 10 and 30 year yields drift further from recent peaks. Conversely, the DXY has eased back a bit more from its peaks around 91.900 to sub-91.800.

BANK RESEARCH HIGHLIGHTS: JPM sees oil above USD 80/bbl, GS technicals sees SPX recovering to 2776 before drop to 2462, Barclays recommends short EURUSD, MS likes USDRUB, Citi likes USDSEK, and UBS on this week's two key trade deadlines
content:
• TRADE: UBS reminds us that there are two key US trade policy decisions due this week: 1) Whether to roll steel and aluminium tariff exemptions (1/May), and 2) NAFTA decision (possibly by 4/May). 
  • CRUDE: JPMorgan joins BAML in seeing oil moving above $80/bbl, arguing that short-term risks are skewed to the upside. 
  • FOREX: Meanwhile, after jumping by over 2.5% from April lows, more desks are joining the 'long USD' party; Barclays trade of the week looks for EURUSD at 1.1739, while from a technical perspective, Goldman says a break of 1.2076-1.2032 could open the way to 1.1829-1.17. Citi's preferred expression is to long USDSEK as their trade of the week, .while Morgan Stanley likes a long USDRUB as their trade of the week. (Note that some FX rebalancing models looked for mild USD selling heading into month-end).
  • EQUITIES: Goldman also sees a recovery in the SPX to 2776, though maintains its high conviction technical view that a correction to 2462 is on the cards. Capital Economics has also recently warned of tougher times ahead for US stocks.

subject: Fixed Income: consolidation ahead of US open
content: Core EU bonds remain on divergent paths as the am session draws to a close , with the futures spread between Bunds and Gilts around 30 ticks wider even though both 10 year benchmarks are off their extremes. Note, the latter extended its Liffe intraday best to 122.31 at one stage (+38 ticks), but has drifted back in line with debt counterparts ahead of the US open and a pretty busy line up for month end. Back to Eurex, or rather Eurozone inflation linkers and a flattener is favoured by Soc Gen along the 10-30 year German curve via 2030-2046 maturities on a weighted basis. The rationale is that once the ECB signals the end of QE (by December 2018) the long end will lag amidst broad repricing for higher yields. Turning to the periphery, BTPs are seeing more selling pressure on latest headlines as the Italian 5-star leader calls for another election.Core EU bonds remain on divergent paths as the am session draws to a close , with the futures spread between Bunds and Gilts around 30 ticks wider even though both 10 year benchmarks are off their extremes. RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 30th April 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • M&A action in focus as Sainsbury’s surges up 20% on Asda merger news
  • Markets largely tepid in anticipation of US core PCE price index
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, German national CPI, US PCE Price Index and Personal Consumption
  •  

ASIA

Asian equity markets were positive but with gains mostly modest amid a holiday-quietened start for the region and ahead of the key risk events this week including the FOMC meeting and US NFP jobs data. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and KOSPI (+0.7%) were higher although weakness across Australia’s commodity sectors restricted upside, while South Korea continued to benefit from improving ties following Friday’s summit and after North Korea vowed to close its nuclear test site. Hang Seng (+1.7%) was the outperformer of the region with the index propped up by China’s largest banks following improved earnings reports and with sentiment also underpinned by better than expected Chinese Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data. As a reminder, both Japan and mainland China were closed for holidays with Japan to only open Tuesday and Wednesday amid Golden Week, while China is shut today and tomorrow due to Labour Day.

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 51.4 vs. Exp. 51.3 (Prev. 51.5). (Newswires)

Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 54.8 vs. Exp. 54.5 (Prev. 54.6)

Chinese Composite PMI (Apr) 54.1 (Prev. 54.0)

China is said to be planning trade offers for the US delegation including US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin when they visit this week. Reports stated that Beijing is likely to offer to import more goods from US to reduce and offer to negotiate a free trade agreement as well as other measures. (WSJ)

EU/UK/US

UK PM May accepted the resignation of Home Secretary Amber Rudd amid claims that Rudd misled parliament regarding targets for increasing immigrant deportations, which she had denied at a House of Commons committee. Sajid Javid appointed as new Home Secretary. (Sky News)

Italy’s 5 Star movement leaders are against forming a government with the Democratic party. With further news from Italy’s centre-right saying they may seek minority government mandate. (Newswires)

Regional German CPIs have painted a broadly similar picture to expectations for the mainland readings (1300BST) with a decline in the M/M and Y/Y relatively unchanged from the previous. Increases in energy and food prices were offset by a fall in the core rate. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

EU bourses opened mixed, but since then traded in positive territory (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) with modest gains as the region follows suit from Asia overnight. Looking at the sectors, Telecoms are outperforming following the merger of Deutsche Telekom’s (+1.3%) T-Mobile and Softbank’s Sprint; Vodafone (+1.6%) and Orange (+0.4%) higher in sympathy. Energy is the worst performing sector with names subdued amid declining oil prices, BP (-0.8%), Shell (-0.7%) and Total (-0.8%) shares are lower as a result. In terms of stock specifics; Sainsbury’s (+15.0%) shares soared on a merger with Walmart’s ASDA touted at around GBP 12bln. Shares in competitors are lower on this news, with Tesco (-1.2%) at the foot of the FTSE 100.

FX

DXY

The Dollar is firmer vs all G10 peers approaching the end of April and a positive 1st month of Q2, with the index forming a solid base above 91.500. Rebalancing models are somewhat mixed, but indicating moderate Usd demand overall, while some are also positioning for a potential positive inflation assessment from this week’s FOMC and already looking ahead to Friday’s NFP.

AUD/NZD

The weakest G10 links and still looking prone to further downside if 0.7550 and 0.7050 fail to hold amidst declines in commodity prices and holiday-thinned trade with China and Japan closed. Little support gleaned from better than expected Chinese PMIs, as the cross pivots 1.0700 ahead of the RBA meeting overnight that is not seen deviating from the neutral stance.

GBP  

Sterling remains under pressure and on course to end a 13 year sequence of gains vs the Usd in the month of April after a dramatic change in fortunes in the last 2 weeks. A run of disappointing data has seen May BoE hike prospects plunge from 90%+ to around 20% or just under, and PMIs in the next 3 days could wipe out tightening expectations altogether if weak. Adding further to the Pound’s woes, another top Government resignation, ongoing doubts about a Brexit deal and a marked reduction in CFTC long positions alongside RHS interest in Eur/Gbp for month end (cross above 0.8800 as a result).

JPY/EUR/CHF/CAD

All around 0.2% down vs the Greenback with Usd/Jpy bouncing off 109.00, but still capped around 109.50, Eur/Usd holding recovery gains above 1.1200 (just) and briefly threatening stops above 1.2140 on a combination of firm German state CPI data and the aforementioned Eur/Gbp demand for month end. Usd/Chf is hovering a few pips below 0.9900 and Usd/Cad is straddling 1.2850 with a retreat in oil prices offsetting latest positive NAFTA noises.

Back to near term policy, MPC’s Haldane is due to speak at 10.00BST and could share more light, but officially the panel should be on lock-down ahead of ‘super’ Thursday next week.

COMMODITIES

Oil falling approaching month end, amidst multiple bearish factors. Firstly, month end rebalancing, in thinner trading conditions due to Chinese and Japanese market holidays, a rise in US rig counts pointing to increased production and a firmer USD placing downward pressure ahead of key US data points such as the core PCE price index ahead of the upcoming Fed meeting. The data in particular focus as some analysts are suggesting that should the YY rate post 2.0% (vs. prev. 1.9%) we will be at the Fed’s stated inflation target, signalling a higher possibility for hawkish tones.

In addition, technical impulses weighing, with USD 67.80 and USD 67.56 support levels tripped in WTI. Note June Brent futures expire later today.

In the metals complex, gold sliding as the risk sentiment continues to improve following reduced Korean tensions, and thereby reducing safe haven demand flows. However, Copper bid following a strong Chinese PMI’s.

subject: Citi trade of the week: Buy USDSEK 8.6775 (target 8.9000, stop 8.5750)
content:
• USD short squeeze chasing: There is further room for a squeeze of positioning in the short term so any strength in this week’s data flow could spur another leg higher in USD, Citi says. Short-term investors were caught flat-footed by recent outperformance from US data flow and the perceived improvement in the geopolitical backdrop, which has seen investors begin to re-price the political risk premium on USD, the bank believes, and suspects that there is scope for more of a flush-out, particularly amid relatively light liquidity over the course of this week’s Asian holidays.
  • This means that USD responsiveness to US data flow may be elevated. Citi doubts that the FOMC meeting will prove a major turning point, but even modest strength from payrolls, ISM and other indicators is likely to support the narrative that the US is pulling away from other countries, the bank writes. By contrast, it will likely take more than isolated data strength abroad to fully reverse expectations that other major economies have slowed somewhat, skewing risk-return to a higher USD.
  • USDSEK is a high octane USD long: USDSEK is one of the best carry pairs in G10 and has underperformed rate spreads despite diverging CB hawkishness, Citi points out. Riksbank's Ingves was fundamentally dovish (still worried about Krona strength) as was the decision to push back the 1st hike by 1Q in the rate path, whereas the Fed is continuing their normalization path.
  • USDSEK has underperformed G10 v SEK: EURSEK is the wrong benchmark for SEK weakness, according to Citi: G10 v SEK isn’t even at recent highs suggesting SEK has room to weaken further on crosses. USDSEK has underperformed both G10 v SEK and EURSEK quite considerably.

content: A weak Eurex open, with the 10 year German debt future trading below last Friday’s 158.66 close within a 158.38-65 range and shrugging off weak m/m retail sales data ahead of the more timely, pivotal and less erratic preliminary state/pan inflation reports for April – Saxony firmer y/y as the first of the 6. DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
27th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets were positive but with gains mostly modest amid a holiday-quietened start for the region and ahead of the key risk events this week including the FOMC meeting and US NFP jobs data. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and KOSPI (+0.7%) were higher although weakness across Australia’s commodity sectors restricted upside, while South Korea continued to benefit from improving ties following Friday’s summit and after North Korea vowed to close its nuclear test site. Hang Seng (+1.7%) was the outperformer of the region with the index propped up by China’s largest banks following improved earnings reports and with sentiment also underpinned by better than expected Chinese Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data. As a reminder, both Japan and mainland China were closed for holidays with Japan to only open Tuesday and Wednesday amid Golden Week, while China is shut today and tomorrow due to Labour Day.

FTSE

Sainsbury (SBRY LN) - Sainsburys and Walmart’s Asda in talks over a GBP 12bln merger. The combined company would be led by Sainsbury’s CEO Mike Coupe, with the holding company of both called Sainsbury’s. This has raised concerns that the enlarged group will cut prices further, with some urging to competition watchdog to step in to avoid this and job losses. Sainsbury’s largest shareholder, Qatar Investment Authority, are supportive of this merger however. (Times)

Gambling names – The US is considering repealing the PASPA act that outlaws betting nationwide, opening up the market to new players. (Guardian) Away from the US news is UK news that UK betting firms have sent a letter to culture secretary Matt Hancock to try an prevent the imposition of a GBP 2 top-bet on fixed odds betting terminals. (BBC)

Banking Names – The customers whom were mis-sold payment protection insurance are to be due an extra GBP 18bln in compensation, as according to analysts. (FT)

WPP (WPP LN) – Former CEO Martin Sorrell has been approached by CVC Capital Partners for a potential sale of its market research arm, Kantar. (FT)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – the co.’s mining subsidiaries in DR Congo have been served freezing orders for unpaid royalties of close to USD 3bln by a company associated with Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

THOMAS COOK GROUP (TCG LN) INITIATED WITH A BUY RATING AT JEFFERIES

VICTREX (VCT LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

MORRISONS (MRW LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM AT EXANE BNP PARIBAS

DAX

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – The co. are to merge with T-Mobile (TMUS), to form a co. with an enterprise value of USD146bln. The co. will hold approx. 40% of the combined entity after the merger between T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S), as well as holding voting rights and board control, with a deal set to sign this week, as according to sources. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY) – The co. has failed in trying to protect itself from authorities reviewing its documents seized in a raid (Stuttgarter Zeitung)

RWE (RWE GY) – Nuclear power station lifespans will not be extended, Vattenfall and RWE are en route to get around EUR 1bln compensation for suffering under Germany’s policy of exiting nuclear power. (Tageszeitung)

Continental (CON GY) / OSRAM (OSR GY) – Co.’s expects to achieve double-digit sales growth over the next five years at their 50/50 JV OSRAM Continental; according to managers. (Automobilwoche)   

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Uniper (UN01 GY) / Fortum (FORTUM FH) – Fortum said on Saturday that Russian authorities approved the acquisition of close to 50% of Uniper. (Newswires)

CAC

Sanofi (SAN FP) – The FDA is to conduct a priority review of Cemiplimab as a potential treatment for advanced cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. (Newswires)

Accorhotels (AC FP) – Co. agrees to purchase Movenpick Hotels for CHF 560mln. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Natixis (KN FP) – Francois Riahi is to become CEO as of June 1st. (Newswires)

SMI

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – Credit Suisse, JP Morgan (JPM) and three other Western banks are planning how to handle a loan of CHF 350mln granted to Russian investor Viktor Vekselberg, who is subject to US sanctions (Schweiz am Wochenende)

Roche (ROG SW) – Chairman says that new medicines will compensate the decline in sales as a result of loss of patent protections for three main products, adding that the Co. is less concerned with short-term financial results than with company’s long-term prospects. (Sonntagszeitung)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

PAN EUROPE

Luxottica (LUX IM) – Q1 net EUR 2.14bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.2bln, Q1 sales -10.7% at current FX and affirms FY outlook. (Newswires)  

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) / Vivendi (VIV FP) – Telecom Italia CEO said his position in the Co. will be “untenable” if activist fund Elliott wins the majority of board seats at a shareholder’s vote on Friday. (Sunday Telegraph)

Uni Banca (UBI IM) – CEO and Chairman of Co. were sent to trial with 28 people on Friday over alleged governance irregularities. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

VISCOFAN (VIS SM) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERG

SCANDINAVIA

Seb (SEBA SS) – Q1 operating profit at SEK 5.3bln vs. prev. SEK 4.2bln, net interest income of SEK 4.988bln vs. Exp. SEK 4.984bln. The co. says they remain committed to their cost cap of SEK 22blbn for 2018. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

LUNDIN PETROLEUM (LUPE SS) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT DNB MARKETS

US

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.15% at 2670, NDX +0.10% at 6656, DJI -0.05 at 24310.

Energy -1.2%, Materials -0.2%, Industrials -0.1%, Consumer discretionary +0.5%, Consumer staples +0.6%, Healthcare +0.5%, Financials +0.1%, IT -0.3%, Telecoms +1.8%, Utilities +1.0%.

Equity futures are negative for the week, but closed out the week on a whimper, with most of the action horizontal – there was some negative ticks in afternoon trade, though the ES was content to consolidate beneath the 2670.  M&A: Reports suggest that Sprint (S) is seeking to finalise its merger with T-Mobile (TMUS) which could come as soon as next week. Praxair (PX) and Linde AG received CFIUS clearance for their business combination, and the deal is seen completing in the second half of the year.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets were positive but with gains mostly modest amid a holiday-quietened start for the region and ahead of the key risk events this week
content:
• Asian equity markets were positive but with gains mostly modest amid a holiday-quietened start for the region and ahead of the key risk events this week
  • In FX markets, most major currencies consolidated heading into month-end and amid this week’s market closures
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German regional and national CPI, US PCE Price Index, Personal Consumption

ASIA

Asian equity markets were positive but with gains mostly modest amid a holiday-quietened start for the region and ahead of the key risk events this week including the FOMC meeting and US NFP jobs data. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and KOSPI (+0.7%) were higher although weakness across Australia’s commodity sectors restricted upside, while South Korea continued to benefit from improving ties following Friday’s summit and after North Korea vowed to close its nuclear test site. Hang Seng (+1.7%) was the outperformer of the region with the index propped up by China’s largest banks following improved earnings reports and with sentiment also underpinned by better than expected Chinese Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data. As a reminder, both Japan and mainland China were closed for holidays with Japan to only open Tuesday and Wednesday amid Golden Week, while China is shut today and tomorrow due to Labour Day.

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 51.4 vs. Exp. 51.3 (Prev. 51.5). (Newswires)
Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 54.8 vs. Exp. 54.5 (Prev. 54.6)
Chinese Composite PMI (Apr) 54.1 (Prev. 54.0)

China is said to be planning trade offers for the US delegation including US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin when they visit this week. Reports stated that Beijing is likely to offer to import more goods from US to reduce and offer to negotiate a free trade agreement as well as other measures. (WSJ)


UK/EU

UK PM May accepted the resignation of Home Secretary Amber Rudd amid claims that Rudd misled parliament regarding targets for increasing immigrant deportations, which she had denied at a House of Commons committee. (Sky News)

Britain is set to make an offer to the EU on future immigration which would see arrangements “very similar” to current free movement rules put in place post- Brexit. (Independent)

UK Brexit Secretary Davis has downplayed reports that he might resign unless Theresa May sidelines Whitehall’s top civil servant working on Britain’s exit from the EU. (Guardian)

S&P affirmed UK at AA; Outlook Negative and affirmed Germany at AAA; Outlook Stable. Fitch affirmed UK at AA; Outlook Negative and affirmed Netherlands at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

German Economic Affairs and Energy Minister Altmaier said that the EU should offer trade talks with US. (Newswires)

UK Lloyds Business Barometer (Apr) M/M 32 (Prev. 32). (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, most major currencies consolidated heading into month-end and amid this week’s market closures. As such, the DXY was flat around 91.50 and EUR/USD remained firm following Friday’s rebound, while GBP/USD languished at a sub-1.3800 level after last week’s poor GDP numbers saw money markets price in only just a 20% chance of a hike next week vs. 50% prior to the release. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies pulled-back amid lacklustre trade in the underlying complex, and USD/JPY found support at 109.00 although lacked the usual gotobi demand gusto with participants absent in Tokyo, while CNH was supported on the back of the encouraging PMI data.

New Zealand ANZ Business Confidence (Apr) -23.4% (Prev. -20.0%). (Newswires)
New Zealand ANZ Activity Outlook (Apr) 17.8% (Prev. 21.8%)


COMMODITIES 

Commodities were lacklustre overnight amid holiday-quietened conditions and as the USD held steady, which saw WTI crude futures marginally retreat below the USD 68/bbl level. Elsewhere, gold pulled back from prior resistance around USD 1325.00/oz amid a positive risk-tone, while copper in turn benefited from the sentiment but with only marginal amid the absence of its largest consumer China.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (27 Apr) 1021 (Prev. 1013). (Newswires)

Rusal's Deripaska has reportedly agreed to cut his stake in EN+ (which holds a controlling interest in Rusal) to below 50% and resign. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

South Korea and North Korea signed the Panmunjeom Declaration on Friday which was said to minimize economic cooperation but provided room for future possibility. In addition, there were also reports over the weekend that North Korea pledged to shut its nuclear test site in May. (Newswires)

US President Trump welcomed progress between North and South Korea, while he is said to meet with Kim in the coming weeks. (Newswires)

French President Macron and Iranian President Rouhani agreed to cooperate on preserving the Iranian nuclear agreement. (Newswires)


US

The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Friday, with short-dated yields narrowing by around 1bps, while the longer-end of the curve saw yields drop by around 5bps at settlement. The buying resulted in further narrowing of major curve spreads – on the week, 2s30s narrows by around 3bps, 5s30s narrowed by around 2bps, while 2s10s flattened by around 2bps in the week. There was some selling action after better than expected US GDP on Friday, though the selling was reversed shortly afterwards, as the sell-off in tech shares prompted buying in the long-end of the curve.

GOP-led House panel ended its Russia investigation and stated that there was no evidence Trump colluded with Russia during the presidential election. (Guardian)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said the US plans to extend steel and aluminium tariff relief for some countries but not all, when they expire on May 1st. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Asia begins holiday-quietened & risk-packed week positive, with Hang Seng leading on better than expected Chinese PMI data and big bank earnings
content:
Asia equity markets are positive but with gains mostly modest amid a holiday-quietened start for the region and ahead of the key risk events this week including the FOMC meeting and US NFP jobs data. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and KOSPI (+0.6%) are positive with weakness across Australia’s commodity sectors restricting upside, while South Korea continues to benefit from improving ties following Friday’s summit and with North Korea vowing to close its nuclear test site. Hang Seng (+1.7%) is the outperformer of the region with the index propped up by China’s largest banks following improved earnings reports and with sentiment also underpinned by better than expected Chinese Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data. As a reminder, both Japan and mainland China are closed for holidays with Japan to only open Tuesday and Wednesday amid Golden Week, while China is shut today and tomorrow due to Labour Day.

In FX markets, most major currencies are consolidating heading into month-end and amid this week’s market closures. As such, the DXY-index is flat around 91.50 and EUR/USD remains firm following Friday’s rebound, while GBP/USD languishes at a sub-1.3800 level after last week’s poor GDP numbers saw money markets price in only just a 20% chance of a hike next week vs. 50% prior to the release. Elsewhere, USD/JPY found support at 109.00 although lacks the usual gotobi demand gusto with participants absent in Tokyo, while CNH is supported on the back of the encouraging PMI data.
